source.title: History of ancient pottery.

p0znh3t5s5w.label: Fine Style
p0znh3t5s5w.editorialNote:
Author apparently miscalculates Start date as "Ol. XCIV, B.C. 403". The 94th Olympiad would range from 400 to 396 BC (ISO values: -399 to -395). I have opted to use his more precise dating of "B.C. 403" as a precise Start.

It is unclear whether author indicates the lifespan or the reign of Pyrrhus when indicating "the time of Pyrrhus" as the period in which the florid style gradually replaced the fine style. I have therefore opted for the wider range (Pyrrhus' life) to infer an earliest and latest stop. cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyrrhus_of_Epirus#cite_note-1
p0znh3t5s5w.note:
p.285: "The age of these vases is fixed by the appearance of the long vowels, the changed form of the aspirate, and the presence of the double or aspirated letters, introduced into the public acts after the archonship of Euclid, Olympiad XCIV., B.C. 403."

p.288-90: "It is by no means necessary to suppose that one style of fabric ceased immediately on the introduction of another and improved one; on the contrary, it probably continued till so entirely superseded that the fabric became obsolete. Hence the transition from the 'fine' style of the earlier vases to a subsequent one, which may be termed florid -- analogous to the state of art in the time of Pyrrhus."

p0znh3tjnv8.label: Strong Style
p0znh3tjnv8.note:
p. 282: "The age of these vases is placed between the L. and LXXX. Olympiads. Recent discoveries have shown that vases of this style are as old as the Parthenon, destroyed by the Persians, Ol. LXXV., B.C. 480, and certainly prior to the age of Pheidias. [see note 3] The vases with the historical subjects of Alcaeus, Ol. XLII., B.C. 612; Anacreon, Ol. LV., B.C. 560; and Croesus, Ol. LVIII., B.C. 548, are in this style. The alphabet resembles that which appears in the Athenian inscriptions of Ol. LXXXVI., B.C. 436, but the language is both Attic and Doric."

p.282 n.3: "Jahn, Vasensammlung, s. clxxiv. clxxv; Allg. Monatsschr, 1852, p. 356."

p0znh3tjqgh.label: Decadence
p0znh3tjqgh.note:
p. 296: "The vases of this style at its best period are later than the introduction of the double letters in the Archonship of Euclid, Olympiad XCIV, B.C. 404, and come down to nearly B.C. 200. [see note 4]"

p.296, n. 4: "Thiersch., s. 81-2"

p0znh3t4t68.label: Florid Style
p0znh3t4t68.editorialNote: It is unclear whether the author means the lifespan or reign of Pyrrhus in his description. I have therefore inferred a Start and Stop date from Pyrrhus' lifespan (the broader range). cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyrrhus_of_Epirus#cite_note-1
p0znh3t4t68.note: p. 288-290: "It is by no means necessary to suppose that one style of fabric ceased immediately on the introduction of another and improved one; on the contrary, it probably continued till so entirely superseded that the fabric became obsolete. Hence the transition from the 'fine' style of the earlier vases to a subsequent one, which may be termed florid--analogous to the state of art in the time of Pyrrhus."

p0dfxxpp4m9.label: Epipaleolithic
p0dfxxpp4m9.note: Modified from Shea (2013*: 7, table 1.1), whose focus is on the Levant. *Stone Tools in the Paleolithic and Neolithic Near East. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge. This end date is calibrated. The time range for the Epipaleolithic varies considerably, based on regions. For the mainland, the range is generally that given in this table; this is also when calibrated dates typically are used. However, for most Mediterranean islands, the Epipaleolithic often starts much later and continues into what is generally considered Neolithic on the mainland.

p0dfxxpf8hv.label: Lower Paleolithic
p0dfxxpf8hv.note: Modified from Shea (2013*: 7, table 1.1), whose focus is on the Levant. This rough chronology is primarily uncalibrated; calibration is only relevant for more recent periods, and even for these, most dates, particularly from earlier research, are presented as uncalibrated. *Stone Tools in the Paleolithic and Neolithic Near East. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

p0dfxxpcnkv.label: Aceramic Neolithic
p0dfxxpcnkv.note: Modified from Shea (2013*: 7, table 1.1), whose focus is on the Levant. *Stone Tools in the Paleolithic and Neolithic Near East. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge. These start & end dates are calibrated. A large regional chronological variability is observed here, as with the Epipaleolithic. Typically, the Neolithic on the islands is later than on the mainland, having derived from that region. However, an early Neolithic contemporary with that of the mainland has been recently documented in Cyprus; thus, the wide chronological framework is used here, which includes both Pre-Pottery and Pottery phases.

p0dfxxptx7v.label: Upper Paleolithic
p0dfxxptx7v.note: Modified from Shea (2013*: 7, table 1.1), whose focus is on the Levant. This rough chronology is primarily uncalibrated; calibration is only relevant for more recent periods, and even for these, most dates, particularly from earlier research, are presented as uncalibrated. *Stone Tools in the Paleolithic and Neolithic Near East. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

p0dfxxp54v2.label: Middle Paleolithic
p0dfxxp54v2.note: Modified from Shea (2013*: 7, table 1.1), whose focus is on the Levant. This rough chronology is primarily uncalibrated; calibration is only relevant for more recent periods, and even for these, most dates, particularly from earlier research, are presented as uncalibrated. *Stone Tools in the Paleolithic and Neolithic Near East. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

source.title: Beta maṣāḥǝft: Manuscripts of Ethiopia and Eritrea

p03tcss.editorialNote:
The project Beta maṣāḥǝft: Manuscripts of Ethiopia and Eritrea (Schriftkultur des christlichen Äthiopiens: eine multimediale Forschungsumgebung) is a long-term project funded within the framework of the Academies' Programme (coordinated by the Union of the German Academies of Sciences and Humanities) under survey of the Akademie der Wissenschaften in Hamburg. The funding will be provided for 25 years, from 2016–2040. The project is hosted by the Hiob Ludolf Centre for Ethiopian Studies at the University of Hamburg. It aims at creating a virtual research environment that shall manage complex data related to predominantly Christian manuscript tradition of the Ethiopian and Eritrean Highlands.

The periods list is based on the traditional subdivision of Ethiopian history as it appears in E. Cerulli, La letteratura etiopica (Florence: Sansoni, 1968).

"Second Period (or period of the Hyk'sos rule), from 2080 to 1527." page 17.
"The Second Period is the era covered by the rule of the Hyksos, or Shepherd Kings, and lasts for about five centuries (2080 - 1525 b.c.)."
"Ancient Egypt comprised three divisions, — Lower Egypt, or the Delta ; Middle Egypt, or the Heptanomis ; Upper Egypt, or the Thebais." page 13.

"The Roman Republic", page 136.

p0pf7xr7sbd.label: Third Period
p0pf7xr7sbd.note:
"Third Period (or period of the new empire), from 1527 to 525." page 17.

"Ancient Egypt comprised three divisions, — Lower Egypt, or the Delta ; Middle Egypt, or the Heptanomis ; Upper Egypt, or the Thebais." page 13.

source.title: SIA+ Chrono-Cultural Categories
source.abstract:
The document shows the chrono-cultural categories that are employed to classify archaeological entities within the Sistema de Información Arqueológica (Archaelogical Information System, SIA+) of Incipit CSIC.
Chrono-cultural categories are not exactly periods. They have strong chronological semantics but also possess cultural meaning. This is an arguable way to categorise archaeological entities, but nevertheless they have been used by Incipit CSIC on the SIA+ for over 18 years, and currently characterise over 200.000 entities from Galicia and neighbouring areas in NW Spain.

source.title: Digital Index of North American Archaeology (DINAA)
source.abstract: The Digital Index of North American Archaeology (DINAA) project is developing the first online, integrated, and comprehensive database of evidence for North America’s human settlement. DINAA provides a free and open framework to examine multidisciplinary questions of human-environmental relationships, at multiple geospatial and temporal scales. The project launched in 2011 as a publicly accessible compilation of existing archaeological site file, collection, and report data from multiple regional, state, and local repositories, linked with environmental and paleoenvironmental datasets. DINAA embraces current best practices in scientific data-management. These include open standards and open licensing, transparent version control (of both data and source code), Linked Data, and iterative development. In consultation and cooperation with government, academic, and tribal stakeholders, our team is now completing the first ‘proof of concept’ phase of the project. We have already linked site file information from much of the eastern United States, demonstrating the capability to develop a truly continental database.

source.title: Über den Styl und die Herkunft der bemahlten griechischen Thongefässe.

p08x7czx9ff.label: Strenger Styl
p08x7czx9ff.editorialNote: cf. p. 113-114 for author's overview of letter forms found on these vases, which forms his principal basis for a date range.
p08x7czx9ff.note:
p. 114: " Diese Inschriften aber geben uns
hier, wie in den beiden vorhergehenden Klassen, den einzigen festen Anhaltpunkt, um die Epoche dieser Gcfäfse, mit einiger Bestimmtheit wenigstens, angeben zu könne."

p08x7cz8f39.label: Alter Styl
p08x7cz8f39.note:
p.92: "Schwieriger und unsicherer ist es, die Zeit festzustellen,in welche etwa der Anfang dieser Kunslweise zu setzen ist, und ich sehe keinen festen Punkt, woran man eine sichere Schlufsfolge knüpfen könnte. Doch ist die Betrachtung nicht ohne Gewicht, dafs, bei allerdings vorhandenen Unterschieden in der Behandlung, doch im Ganzen sämmlliche Gefäfse dieses Styls ein ziemlich gleichartiges Gepräge tragen, und defshalb die einzelnen der Zeit nach wohl schwerlich zu weit auseinandcrliegen mögen. Bedenkt man aufserdem die allgemeinen Zeitverhältnisse, welche auch auf diesen Kunslzweig
ihren Einflufs ausüben mufsten, so wird die Annahme, welche auch Gerhard und Bunsen schon aussprachen, nicht ganz unbegründet erscheinen, dafs der Anfang eines eifrigen Betriebs desselben etwa in die Zeit der persischen Kriege zu setzen sei. Hiernach würden die Gefäfse dieses Styls im Ganzen und Grofsen etwa als zwischen Ol. 70 und 80. gefertigt angesehen werden könne"

p.92-3, n. 1: "Gerhard (s. Rapp. volc. p.53. Not. 4SI und 9''l9. *)) bezieht ein kleineres panathenäisches Preisgefäfs, auf dessen Rückseite ein Kitharöde dargestellt ist (s. Beil. antike Bildw. No. 649.), auf die von Perikles bei den Panathenäen eingeführten musischen Kampfe, so wie Bröndsted (l. c.) dem Emblem einer Sirene mit Doppelflöten,
welches auf dem Schilde der Athena mehrerer panathenäischen Preisgefäfse erscheint, dieselbe Beziehung unterlegt. Sind beide Vermuthungen auch wirklich richtig (die erstere namentlich hat gewifs viel Empfehlendes) und fallt auch jene Einfühlung noch später, als Ol.80., wohin sie Gerhard setzt (s. Plut. Pericl. c. 13.), so wird dadurch die obige Bestimmung keinesweges umgestofsen, namentlich da die stumpfen Mahlereien jenes Gefäfses anzudeuten scheinen, dafs, als sie gemacht wurden, diese Kunstweise nicht eben mehr gewöhnlich
war (s. oben S. 85.)."

p0gjgrsmhnc.note: This period does not appear in the EH timeline. When this broad period is used, the database will automatically map it onto either Iron Age (for the earlier coins) or Roman (for the later coins) depending on the precise years entered.

p0gjgrshhcw.label: Early Medieval
p0gjgrshhcw.note: This period is diverse and must be qualified wherever possible with Early, Middle or Late. The currently accepted chronology (spring 2013) is given below, but this is likely to change in the near future. English Heritage do not specify the boundaries of these sub-periods.

p0gjgrs69ws.note: Can be split into Early and Late.

p0gjgrs45g4.label: Mesolithic
p0gjgrs45g4.note: Can be split into Early and Late.

p0gjgrs6sgx.label: Post-Medieval
p0gjgrs6sgx.note: Early post-medieval is generally used for the 16th century and sometimes for the 17th century. The term 'middle post-medieval' is not used, and there is debate as to what constitutes the late post-medieval period. For the 18th century, it is best to stick simply to 'post-medieval' and qualify it using calendar dates.

p0gjgrs6zcf.label: Palaeolithic
p0gjgrs6zcf.note: Generally split into Lower, Middle and Upper, which we will translate into Early, Middle and Late.

3.http://ljzlcl.blog.163.com/blog/static/9666123620090433033441/

NOTES:

This table of major Chinese States and Dynasties provides a basic time frame, and includes both the overall periods, as well as specific sub-periods, or in most cases, specific states.

For example, the Northern and Southern Dynasties is listed (420 CE - 577 CE), along with the various states, such as Liu Song, Eastern Wei, and so on that existed during that period.    Note that the overall period is not itself a "state" and has no capital, nor any administration or political history.  It is merely a superset of many states.

By contrast there are Periods, with Sub-periods, such as the Song Dynasty, which was one continuous political entity, but is divided into two very distinct periods, the Northern Song and Southern Song, reflecting the incursion of the Mongols who seized the greater part of the northern area of the Song, and forced the capital to be relocated from Kaifeng to Hangzhou.

partOf.title: Exploration and exploitation in the macrohistory of the pre-Hispanic Pueblo Southwest

p0m9pcg.editorialNote: These are revised Pecos period definitions (including subperiods) derived explicitly from a large database of tree-ring cutting dates from across the Ancestral Pueblo Southwest. Basketmaker III is truncated to start at AD 500; Pueblo IV is truncated to end at AD 1400; all periods are rounded to the nearest 5th year. We wanted to identify the points in time when the rate of change in the cutting-date frequency was transitioning from slowing down to accelerating, to break up Fig. 2B into five Pecos periods (and their subperiods) based on the four primary “humps” in the cutting-date frequency distribution. To do so, we calculated the modal inflection points (the points at which a continuous vector switches from being concave to being convex, or vice versa) in a series of kernel density estimates of the number of cells with cutting dates through time (Fig. 2B), each using a Gaussian kernel (that is, a normal distribution). Because the smoothness of kernel density distributions is determined by the kernel bandwidth (here, the SD of the Gaussian kernel), we estimated inflection points for density distributions with kernel bandwidths ranging from 0.01 to 50 years, in 0.01-year increments (5000 kernel density estimates). For each density distribution, we calculated a series of inflection points as the years where the second derivative of the kernel density estimate function was zero. Kernel distributions with very small bandwidths will have many inflection points, whereas those with large bandwidths (that is, very smooth distributions) will only have a few. The inflection points of each of the kernel density distributions were combined to calculate the 10 most common inflection years. Inflection years were rounded to the nearest fifth year. One break in the P IV period (at A.D. 1365) was discarded because P IV was determined to not fit the demographic and organizational pattern of the earlier periods. All source code for defining these periods are available at http://advances.sciencemag.org/cgi/ content/full/2/4/e1501532/DC1.

p06c6g3bb4p.note: Extracted from heading "New Zealand--History--New Zealand Wars, 1843-1847". Added to LCSH in 2004. Sources cited: Belich, J. The New Zealand wars and the Victorian interpretation of racial conflict, 1986: p. 204 (three local outbreaks of conflict took place between 1843 and 1847) p. 212 (The period 1847-60 was one of peace between Māori and Pākehā); Oxford hist. of N.Z., 1981: p. 148 (The central role of land in the wars between Māori and Pāehā has often been remarked; sometimes they have been called the Land Wars); The New Zealand Wars web site, Sept. 19, 2003 (The New Zealand Wars were fought in New Zealand between 1843 and 1872) what's in a name (the Maori Wars; the Land Wars; Nga Pakanga Nu Nui o Aotearoa; Nga pakanga o Aotearoa; the Anglo-Maori Wars; the Colonial New Zealand Wars; new Zealand Civil Wars; the overwhelmingly favourite name used these days is undoubtedly the New Zealand Wars).
p06c6g3bb4p.label: New Zealand Wars, 1843-1847
p06c6g3bb4p.editorialNote: This LCSH record seems to have been reconciled by the Ngā Upoko Tukutuku / Māori Subject Headings service of the New Zealand National Library as Ngā Pakanga Whenua o Mua (https://natlib.govt.nz/nga-upoko-tukutuku/ng%C4%81-pakanga-whenua-o-mua), preferred to Ngā Pakanga o Aotearoa (https://natlib.govt.nz/nga-upoko-tukutuku/ng%C4%81-pakanga-o-aotearoa).

source.title: Berlin's antike Bildwerke

p02q72z37m3.label: Zweiten Periode
p02q72z37m3.note: Period label: "Einer zweiten Periode, welche in jenen, hauptsächlich den Gefäfsen etruskischer Auffindung angehörigen Zeitraum." Spatial coverage: "...fallen denn, ebenfalls aus paläographischen und zugleich aus artistischen Gründen, die meisten Vasen Siciliens und Kampaniens, hauptsächlich Nola's anheim". Gerhard identifies a third period that follows this one; it is characterized by works from Apulia and Lucania, but is not given any absolute dates: "dagegen eine dritte spätere Periode jener Vasenfabrikation den apulischen und lukanischen Vasen beizumessen ist." (1836, 144).
p02q72z37m3.editorialNote: Gerhard's dating is based on letter forms matched to the historical record and placed chronologically by Olympiad. See also citation of this source in Birch 1858 (p. 221).

p02q72z6c67.label: Vorgerückten Kunstsitte
p02q72z6c67.note: Period label: "Vasen mit denen einer vorgerückten Kunstsitte". Spatial coverage: "von Volci aus alle umliegenden Gegenden Etruriens mit Thongefäfsen griechischer Kunst". Dates based principally on the appearance of distinct Greek letter forms on some of the vases within the museum collection. From Gerhard 1836, 144: "Fast alle dort gefundenen Vaseninschriften zeigen uns einen allgemeinen Gebrauch des simonideischen Alphabets, während sie mit wenigen Ausnahmen die euklideischen Doppelvokale verleugnen, wonach denn für die Mehrzahl jener Gefäfse der Zeitabschnitt von Olymp. LXXIV bis Olymp. XCIV begrenzend eintritt."
p02q72z6c67.editorialNote: See also Birch (1858, p. 221), who cites this page in Gerhard, though note that he attributes the starting point to Olymp. LXXXIV (444 BCE) in an apparent misreading of Gerhard's text.

p0pp7vzrffc.label: Style Proto-Élamite, Deuxième Période
p0pp7vzrffc.note: "Sur la seconde catégorie du style proto-élamite et sur les liens de suture qui existent entre la première période, placée avant l'an 3000 av. J.-C., et la deuxième période, placée par approximation vers 3000 au 2800, voir notre [Pottier's] étude sur les vases peints de l'Acropole de Suse, dans les 'Mémoirs de la délégation en Perse', t. XIII (1912), p. 41 et sv., p. 61-62, p. 144 et sv.; et dans le 'Catalogue des antiquités de la Susiane au Musée du Louvre', par M. Pézard et E. Pottier, le chapitre sur la céramique, p. 230 et sv., p. 236 à 238"

p0pp7vz82n6.label: Style Attique à Figures Noires
p0pp7vz82n6.note: "Nous ne citerons ici que les publications générales les plus récentes qui présentent une vue d'ensemble sur la fabrication classique du VIe et du Ve siècle, pour les vases à figures noires et à figures rouges. Voir pour la France: Pottier, 'Catalogue des vases du Musée du Louvre, IIIe partie, l'École Attique.--Perrot, 'Hist. de l'art', tome X.--Dugas, article 'Vasa' du 'Dict. des Antiq.' de Saglio.--Pour l'Angleterre: Walters-Birch, 'History of ancient Pottery', tome I.--Pour l'Italie: Ducati, 'Storia della ceramica greca' (en cours de publication).--Pour l'Allemagne: Furtwaengler-Reichhold-Hauser, 'Griechische Vasenmalerei'.--Hoeber, 'Griech. Vasen'.--Buschor, 'Griech. Vasenmalerei'.--Pfuhl, 'Malerei und Zeichnung der Griechen'."

source.title: A new chart of history. : To Benjamin Franklin LL. D.F.R.S. this chart is, in testimony of esteem & friendship, inscribed by his most obliged humble servt.

p05hrsf3wzm.label: English Georgia
p05hrsf3wzm.editorialNote:
The chart depicts years with a chronological line at the top, radiating from a center point of the birth of Christ. "BC" has been added to the entries where required as illustrated by the structure of the chart, but not actually written.
Spatial coverage has been determined by the labels on the chart running along the right side, separated across the chart with horizontal lines, and narrowed within each horizontal line by smaller areas.
Ending dates of 1770 derived from the year of publication, and also the point at which the chart ends.

Spatial coverage: Georgia, USA

The chart depicts years with a chronological line at the top, radiating from a center point of the birth of Christ. "BC" has been added to the entries where required as illustrated by the structure of the chart, but not actually written.
Spatial coverage has been determined by the labels on the chart running along the right side, separated across the chart with horizontal lines, and narrowed within each horizontal line by smaller areas.
Ending dates of 1770 derived from the year of publication, and also the point at which the chart ends.

fra-latn: Age du bronze (second millénaire av. J.-C.)

p05n4hjrpbm.label: Age du bronze (second millénaire av. J.-C.)

fra-latn: Age du bronze plus récent (seconde partie du second millénaire)

p05n4hj2gr6.label: Age du bronze plus récent (seconde partie du second millénaire)
p05n4hj2gr6.editorialNote: Original cataloguer preferred to use the whole millennium as a date range, but the editors feel that a start that covers the middle third of the millennium is reasonable from context.

p05n4hjrw5p.label: Age néolithique (entre 3000 et 2000 av. J.-C.)
p05n4hjrw5p.editorialNote: Neolithic period collection restricted to Plates 1 and 2
p05n4hjrw5p.note:
Les fouilles de Troie conduites par Schliemann de 1870 à 1890, continuées par Doerpfeld en 1893-94, ont donné lieu à nombreuses publications dont on trouvera les références dans Perrot et Chipiez, 'Hist. de l'art', VI, p. 154 et suiv., p. 895 et suiv.; Dussaud, 'Les Civilisations préhelléniques, 2e édit., p. 118 et suiv. Parmi les principales nous citerons: Schliemann, 'Ilios', 1881; trad. française Egger, 1885; C. Schuchhardt, 'Schliemann's Ausgrahungen', 1891; Doerpfeld, 'Troja und Ilion', 2 vol. 1902; H. Schmidt, 'Trojanisch. Alterthümer', 1902.

Pour le classement des poteries de ce genre, voir, dans la série faite pour l'Union Académique Interntionale, la Classification (n. 7) de D.G. Hogarth, 'Pottery of Asia Minor (except greek colonies)'.

fra-latn: Age du bronze ancien et moyen (second millénaire)

p05n4hjvj7c.label: Age du bronze ancien et moyen (second millénaire)

fra-latn: Age du bronze moyen et plus récent (seconde partie du second millénaire)

p05n4hjrtts.label: Age du bronze moyen et plus récent (seconde partie du second millénaire)
p05n4hjrtts.editorialNote: Original cataloguer preferred to use the whole millennium as a date range, but the editors feel that a start that covers the middle third of the millennium is reasonable from context.
p05n4hjrtts.note: "Caractères généraux: argile blanchatre, plus rarement rouge avec engobe blanc: façonnage à la main ou au tour primitif; décor en noir mat tournant parfois au rouge; formation du style géometrique peint."

p08m57h9pd4.label: South Western British Iron Age
p08m57h9pd4.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Dorset, parts of Somerset, Wiltshire, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The ethnic or tribal identities of the issuers of South Western coinage - which is entirely uninscribed - are unknown, but they are often associated with the Durotriges, who are known to have inhabited this region during the early Roman period.
p08m57h9pd4.spatialCoverageDescription: modern Dorset, parts of Somerset, Wiltshire, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight

p08m57hdwjh.label: Hephthalite
p08m57hdwjh.note: The Hephthalites, also known as the White Huns, were a group of Central Asian nomads who migrated from the Altai region to Transoxiana around AD 420-440, driving out the Kushans (q.v.). After defeat and being made tributary in turn by the Turks in 553 (q.v. 'Turkic'), some Hephthalites may have joined the Avars (q.v.) in their migration to the steppes and Central Europe.

p08m57hz3gh.note: An ancient political unit of India which issued coins between the first century BC and second century AD. The Kuninda are sometimes described as a tribal group, or Janapada, and are referred to as a people in Indian and Western texts. They lived in the region encompassing the tributaries of the Indus and Ganges rivers though little is known about their political or cultural history.

p08m57hn6p3.label: Last Ice Age
p08m57hn6p3.note: The Ice Age refers to the period between 2.6 million and 11,700 years ago during which climate varied through alternating warm and cold periods. Modern humans and many other mammal species evolved during this period.  During some cold stages (glaciations) temperatures dropped so much that continental and alpine ice sheets spread over vast areas. With water frozen to ice, sea levels also dropped providing humans and animals with opportunities to spread out across land bridges which were then submerged again during warm periods such as we live in today. Throughout the Ice Age, Britain formed part of mainland of Europe.  However, 'Ice Age' (as used in the British Museum records) is a term in popular use for the period of warm and cold phases between 126,000 and 11,000 years ago or, more narrowly, to the time after 40,000 years ago when fully modern humans arrived in Europe and North America.  The Pleistocene is a geological term used to refer to the same period of climatic changes as the Ice Age.  The Last Ice Age refers to the period of warm and cold phases between 126,000 and c.11, 000 years ago when fully modern people like us (Homo sapiens sapiens) spread around the earth.

p08m57hdh7z.note: 1206-1370 (AH 602-AH 771). Rulers of Mongolia who conquered China, the 'Abbasid empire, the south Russian steppes and central Europe. The Mongol expansion took place under Genghis Khan in 1209 (AH 606). He took Beijing in 1215 (AH 612) thus controlling numerous commercial routes across central Asia to China. In 1220 (AH 616) Genghis Khan captured Bukhara and soon the whole of Transoxiana was part of the Mongol empire. In 1258 (AH 656) the Mongols sacked Baghdad under Hulegu grandson of Ghengis Khan and founder of the Il-Khanid dynasty (q.v.).

p08m57hvzgb.note: Period of the Later Stone Age of East Africa, particularly the Lake Nakuru - Naivasha Basin region, characterised by large backed blades, crescents, edge retouched flakes and burins mostly made from obsidian. The Eburran dates from c.13,000-8000 and is divided into 5 phases the earliest of which are pre-Neolithic and the last, phase 5, Neolithic including pottery and bones of domesticated animals. Formerly referred to as Aurignacian by Leakey at Gamble's Cave this term has also replaced Kenya Capsian.

p08m57h2cd7.note: Between 1400 and 1200 BC the Hittites established one of the great empires of the ancient Middle East. At its height, the empire (also called the New Kingdom) encompassed central Turkey, north western Syria, and Upper Mesopotamia (north eastern Syria and northern Iraq). By 1300 the Hittite Empire bordered on Egypt and both powers vied for control of wealthy cities on the Mediterranean coast. This led to the Battle of Kadesh with Rameses II (1274 BC).

In such cases, the term 'Late Medieval' is entered as a Material Culture and 'Burgundy' (or its Narrow terms) are entered in Findspot or Production Place or . p08m57hs35q.note: At the height of its power, the Parthian state extended far beyond the modern political borders of Iran. It was ruled by the Arsacid dynasty and its first great ruler Mithradates I defeated his Seleucid overlords in a series of campaigns in the second century BC. Their earliest capital was at Mithradatkirt (modern Nysa) in Turkmenistan but they later established their capital at Ctesiphon in what is now southern Iraq and opposite the previous Seleucid capital of Seleucia on the Tigris. Parthia fought a number of wars with the Romans and at one period held much of Syria. The end of the period is marked by the defeat of the Parthian king Artabanus IV  in AD 224 by an Iranian noble called Ardashir who went on to establish the Sasanian empire.
p08m57hs35q.spatialCoverageDescription: Iran; southern Iraq; much of Syria
p08m57hs35q.label: Parthian

p08m57hz9dg.label: British Iron Age East Anglia
p08m57hz9dg.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 50 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to the modern East Anglia - Norfolk, Suffolk and parts of Cambridgeshire - in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include AESV, ALIIF SCAVO (or similar), ESVPRASTO, ECEN/ECE (if this is not a reference to the Iceni themselves) and ANTED. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Iceni (who can perhaps be equated with the "Cenimagni" mentioned by Caesar - Caesar, De Bello Gallico, V.21).
p08m57hz9dg.spatialCoverageDescription: modern East Anglia - Norfolk, Suffolk and parts of Cambridgeshire

p08m57hj5tb.label: Macedonian Dynasty
p08m57hj5tb.note: Following the wars that led to the unification of Greece under Philip II of Macedon, his son Alexander III (“the Great”) began a series of campaigns eastwards in 333 BC. A series of victories over the Persians culminated in the final battle at Gaugamela in 331 BC. Already ruler over Anatolia and Egypt, he now became ruler of Babylon and went on to extend control as far east as India. Following Alexander’s death in 323 BC, nominal kingship passed to his brother Philip III, with Perdiccas -- commander of the Companion cavalry -- as regent. In 320 BC Perdiccas was assassinated and rule over Babylon was allotted to Seleucus. He was forced out by Antigonus in 316 BC, only to return triumphantly in 312 BC.

p08m57hdff8.label: Eastern British Iron Age
p08m57hdff8.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Essex and Hertfordshire, parts of Kent, Suffolk, Cambridgeshire, Bedfordshire, Northamptonshire, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, in which similar styled coinages are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Notable rulers in this area include Addedomaros, Dubnovellaunos, Tasciovanus, Dias, Rues and Cunobelin. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain unclear, but some may have belonged to the Trinovantes or the Catuvellauni. Both are known from Roman sources describing the administrative structure of the later Roman province, but only the former definitely pre-dated the Roman invasion of AD 43. The term "Northern" was used by Hobbs in the BM catalogue (1996) but is often considered confusing.  J Creighton, Coins and Power in Iron Age Britain, Cambridge (CUP) 2000.  R Hobbs, British Iron Age Coins in the British Museum, London (BMP) 1996.
p08m57hdff8.spatialCoverageDescription: Essex and Hertfordshire, parts of Kent, Suffolk, Cambridgeshire, Bedfordshire, Northamptonshire, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire

p08m57h3sk2.label: Neo-Babylonian Dynasty
p08m57h3sk2.note: Having previously been under the domination of their northerly neighbours, the Assyrians, native rule returned to Babylon in 626 BC, when Nabopolassar seized the throne. He was part of the coalition that would later destroy the Assyrian empire, and set the stage for the rise of the Babylonian empire. Perhaps the most famous king of the dynasty is his son Nebuchadnezzar, who in 598 BC captured Jerusalem and deported some of the population -- an event immortalised in the Bible. After a long and illustrious reign Nebuchadnezzar II died in 562 BC, to be followed by a series of kings with very short reigns. The empire fell in 539 BC when king Cyrus II of Persia overthrew Nabonidus, the last native ruler of Babylon.

p08m57hmdw6.label: Late Antique
p08m57hmdw6.note: The term is traditionally used for the former territories of the Eastern Roman Empire, ie. Greece, Cyprus, eastern Balkans, parts of the Caucasus (Georgia, Armenia, etc.), Asia Minor, Levant, Egypt and parts of Italy, for the 6thC and 7thC AD. For the 4th and 5thC AD, the term Late Roman is preferred. The term ‘Byzantine’ can be used as an alternative .  The term ‘Late Antique’ is not used for the material culture of the former territories of the western Roman empire, ie. Italy, Gaul, Hispania, Britannia and Western North Africa (Mauritania, Tripolitania), for the 6th and 7thC AD. Instead, the term Early Medieval is preferred. Neither is 'Lare Antique' used for the broadly contemporary Sasanian Empire to the East (for which 'Sasanian' is preferred) or 'Early Islamic' and its Narrow Terms.  For non-Roman material (post AD 410) from Britain, the terms 'Sub-Roman' or 'Early Medieval' are used in preference to 'Late Antique'.  N.B. The Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities does not use the term 'Late Antique', see instead the terms 'Roman' and 'Late Roman'.
p08m57hmdw6.spatialCoverageDescription: Greece, Cyprus, eastern Balkans, parts of the Caucasus, Asia Minor, Levant, Egypt and parts of Italy

p08m57hxhb7.note: Dynasty known as Turki Shahi, ruling from Kabul and established as far as Punjab and Kashmir, circa 750 - 850 AD. Became known as Hindu Shahi after they moved capital to Ohind on Indus river in the North-West Froniter (Pakistan) following the capture of Kabul by Arab general Ya'qub b. Layth in 871 AD. On coins they used the titles Spalapati Deva, Samanta Deva and Vakka Deva. Overthrown by Mahmud of Ghazna [q.v.] in a series of campaigns between 1018 and 1026.
p08m57hxhb7.spatialCoverageDescription: Kabul to Punjab and Kashmir; Pakistan

p08m57hkdk9.note: 1501-1722 (AH 907-AH 1135). The family traced its ancestry to Shaykh Safi al-Din who died in 1334 and is buried at the shrine in Adabil in north-western Iran. In 1501 (AH 905) Isma'il defeated the Aq Qoyunlu, seized Azarbaijan and took control of the whole of Persia. He declared Twelver Shi'ism as the state religion of Iran. The Safavids traced their lineage through the seventh Imam, Musa al-Kazim to ‘Ali, the Prophet Muhammad's son in law and his family. In 1514 (AH 920) Isma'il I and his army of Turkmen Qizilbash ('red heads' because of their red caps) suffered a humiliating defeat by the Ottoman Sultan Selim I at the battle of Chaldiran in north-western Iran. His son and successor Tahmasp I was either defending his western and eastern borders or controlling the Qizilbash. The most outstanding ruler of this dynasty was Shah ‘Abbas who drove the Ottomans out of the Azabarjian and established Persian control over the Caucasus and the Persian Gulf. Isfahan became the capital of Safavid Iran. Safavid rule collapsed with the invasion of the country  by the Afghan Ghilzays in 1722 (AH 1135).
p08m57hkdk9.label: Safavid dynasty

p08m57hjq4j.label: Eastern Mediterranean
p08m57hjq4j.note: The term is used by the Greek and Roman Department for objects with multiple centres of production along the Mediterranean coastline from the Aegean to Egypt. It reflects the broad cultural connections between regions at certain periods, particularly the 'International Style' c. 1400 BC-1200 BC. For this reason it is usually for objects from Bronze Age Cypriot sites: after this period, centres of production are better defined. The term is not used for Hellenistic (q.v.) or Roman (q.v.) objects. See also the Place term 'Mediterranean' with Comment 'East Mediterranean' for objects described as 'East Mediterranean' in the records for the Prehistory and Europe Department.  See also the term 'Cypriot' and its Narrow Terms.

p08m57hjhm5.note: The first king of the Akkadian Dynasty (Sargon I) united the whole of Mesopotamia under one ruler. Sargon and his descendants ruled from 2334 BC until around 2190 BC when the empire collapsed owing to invasion and rebellion.   Akkadian is also a language spoken from around 2600 BC until the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Within that period texts written between 2600 BC-2000 BC use the Old Akkadian language. The language then developed into Babylonian (2000 BC onwards) and Assyrian (2000 BC-600 BC) forms.

p08m57hp2vq.label: Kadamba dynasty
p08m57hp2vq.note: 345-525. Ancient royal family of Karnataka that ruled from Banavasi in present day Uttara Kannada district. The dynasty later continued to rule as a feudatory of larger Kannada empires, the Chalukya and the Rashtrakuta empires for over five hundred years during which time they branched into Goa and Hanagal. At the peak of their power under King Kakushtavarma, they ruled large parts of Karnataka.

Hittite campaigns extended though Syria and Mesopotamia until the Hittite army ransacked Babylon in 1595 BC. Shortly after this the Hittite Kingdom was plunged into chaos and Syrian territories were was lost. The last monarch of the Old Kingdom, reigned until about 1500 BC and the following 70 years, the so-called Middle Kingdom has very sparse surviving records.

p08m57hspv3.note: The term refers to a culture from c. 1stC to 3rdC AD. Knowledge of the so-called Indo-Parthians derives largely from coins and a few inscriptions. Some of the names and coin designs suggest links with the Parthians of Iran, but the precise relationship is not clear. In the first century AD the Indo-Parthians seem to have gained control of the region stretching from the Punjab, Sind and Gandhara (north-west Pakistan) to Seistan (south-east Iran). The principal ruler is Gondophares (c. AD 32–60). The title ‘Gondophares’ (Old Persian Vindapharna ‘Winner of Glory’) was adopted by his successors in addition to their given names on coins from Arachosia (Qandahar) and the Punjab. However, in Sind and Seistan they also issued coins in their own right as ‘king’ or ‘king of kings’. This suggests a complex situation of rulers and sub-rulers who owed varying degrees of allegiance to the Indo-Parthian king.
p08m57hspv3.label: Indo-Parthian

p08m57hdjgb.label: Tulunid dynasty
p08m57hdjgb.note: 868-905 (AH 254-AH 292). First local dynasty of Egypt and Syria with some degree of autonomy from the Abbasid caliphate in Baghdad. Ahmad ibn Tulun was a Turkish soldier whose father had been sent as tribute fron Bukhara in the early 9th century. He first came to Egypt as deputy of the 'Abbasid governor there but then became governor himself and extended his power into Palestine and Syria. The age of the Tulunids was a golden age for Medieval Egyptian historians.

In 1174 the line in Sivas was conquered by the Seljuqs of Rum, the line in Malatya and Elbistan fell to the Seljuqs of Rum in 1178.

p08m57hmf57.note: 1081-1307 (AH 473-AH 707). Turkic dynasty which originated in west-central Anatolia with capital at Konya but later spread over most of Anatolia except the western fringes. The Seljuqs of Rum were an offshoot of the Great Seljuqs. After Alp Arslan's victory over the Byzantines, one of the descendants of one of the sons established a local Seljuq sultanate in Anatolia. The Latin conquest of Constantinople in 1204 (AH 600) gave the Seljuqs and oppurtunity to reestablish their power and extend their influence to the Mediterranean. With this and control over northern coastlands a flourishing transit trade developed between Egypt and the eastern Mediterranean across Anatolia to the Black Sea, the Crimea and the lands of the Mongol Golden Hoard. After circa 1225 commercial relations began with Italian trading cities.
p08m57hmf57.label: Seljuqs of Rum

p08m57h54j8.note: Urban civilisation based in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent, today in Pakistan and western India.  Developing out of earlier prehistoric cultures, it flourished over a very wide area between approximately 2,500 and 2,000 BC.  Script was known but is undeciphered today, not least as surviving inscriptions (mostly on seals) are no more than about a dozen characters.  Major settlements, such as Mohenjo-daro and Harappa, were laid out on a grid pattern with drainage and were clearly organised by a central power.  The earliest fragments of woven cotton from the subcontinent come from these sites.  Trade with sites in the Persian Gulf, as well as with settlements on the Oxus, has been substantiated.
p08m57h54j8.label: Indus Civilisation

p08m57h7kgg.note: The Karts or Kurts of eastern Khurasan and northern Afghanistan were an indiginous dynasty who claimed to be heirs of the Ghurids. The Mongols allowed Shams al-Din I Muhammad (1245-1277, AH 643-676) to rule as a vassal prince in Herat and the mountains of Ghur. They remained loyal allies of the Il-Khans of Persia.
p08m57h7kgg.label: Karts of Herat

p08m57hq6sd.note: 1050 BC-750 BC.  The Cypro-Geometric period, some three hundred years in duration, is the first division of the Cypriot Iron Age. Settlements founded during the transitional LCIII period become the urban centres of the city-kingdoms into which the island is divided in historic times. Economic and cultural contacts with the Levantine world with are re-established (or become archaeologically visible) after a short period of isolation; contacts with the Aegean become apparent again somewhat later in this horizon. Important ceramic types include White Painted and Bichrome wares, which are decorated with geometric motifs and often occur in inventive shapes; slightly later, the distinctive Black-on-Red wares are developed on Cyprus, partly as a result of contact with the Levantine world; fine metalworking in bronze abounds, particularly in burials. Inscriptions point to the existence of Greek and Phoenician speakers on the island living alongside the local Cypriot population.
p08m57hq6sd.label: Cypro-Geometric

p08m57h6tvb.note: ca. 1900 BC-1650 BC. The second division of the Cypriot Bronze Age, marking an expansion in the range of pottery types (including White Painted wares which appeared at the end of the EC period), the spread of settlements all over the island (including fortified sites) and the first signs of significant overseas contacts in the form of numerous ceramic exports to surrounding regions. Many artefacts types, including metal goods, are similar to those from the EC and continue in use into the LC. The last phase of Middle Cypriot, MCIII, witnesses a major increase in the economic and cultural dynamism of the island, including the establishment of new coastal settlements.
p08m57h6tvb.label: Middle Cypriot

p08m57hx528.note: 1490-1686 (AH 895-AH 1097). Dynasty ruling in the western part of the Bahmanid Sultanate at Bijapur. The founder of the dynasty was Yusuf Khan, previously a commander and provisional governor for the Bahmanids. He proclaimed his independence in 1489 (AH 895).  The capital Bijapur became a centre for learning and the arts, where Persian literature became part of the Persianisation process in the region. Bijapur was captured by the Mogul emperor Aurangzib Alamgir in 1686 (AH 1097).

p08m57hf7b2.label: Judaean
p08m57hf7b2.note: The term is used in relation to objects produced in ancient Judaea under the Hasmonean (c. 170BC-37BC) and Herodian (37BC-95AD) dynasties and during the two Jewish revolts (The Jewish War 66AD-68AD and The Bar Kochba Revolt 132AD-135AD).     From 301-201BC most of ancient Judaea was under Ptolemaic control; it was then under the Seleucids under Antiochus III Megas. By 40BC Judaea was almost entirely dominated by Rome, and the first king of the Herodian dynasty, Herod I, was appointed by a declaration of the Roman Senate. Coins minted under the Roman Prefects of Judaea ('the Procurators') have the period culture 'Roman Provincial', as do the later imperial coins minted in Judaean cities (e.g. Aelia Capitolina, the new Roman Jerusalem).    The term is not used for the collections in the Department of Greek and Roman. If the object dates to the period before Judaea became a Roman province (about 6AD) the term 'Hellenistic' is used, and if after Rome takes over then the term 'Roman' is used.

p08m57hmxmp.label: Classical World
p08m57hmxmp.note: Classical World is a broad term referring to the civilisations of the ancient Mediterranean from around 1000 BC to 400 AD, centred on the idea of a continuous development of literature, ideas and material culture originating in Aegean Greece and its overseas settlements and later adapted and modified by the Roman state from the time of the late Republic and early Empire. The term was originally defined after the Renaissance by the literary and artistic inheritance of Greece in the fifth and fourth centuries BC and Rome between the first century BC and fourth century AD, but later took on a broader meaning including history, material culture, settlement and economy within much wider chronological and geographical parameters. The term also includes cultures in close proximity to or in contact with Greeks and Romans, such as Cyprus, the non-Greek peoples of Anatolia such as Lycians and Carians, and the Villanovan, Etruscan and Italic communities of Italy. Other cultures, such as Phoenicians and Carthaginians, local peoples of Spain and North Africa (including Dynastic Egypt), Phrygians, Thracians, Scythians, Celts and the Germanic tribes tend to be included under other Top Terms in the thesaurus (Prehistoric, Levantine and Middle Eastern periods and cultures, and Historic European Periods and cultures). Chronologically, the term sometimes is extended to the earlier periods of Greek history before 1000 BC, including the Bronze Age Minoan and Mycenaean civilisations based on the idea of cultural ancestry.

p08m57hhcgp.note: 1250-1517 (AH 648-AH 923). The Mamluks (meaning 'one possessed, slave') arose from the Turkic troops of Ayyubids of Egypt and Damascus. Two lines of Mamluk sultans are distinguished: the Bahri Mamluks and the Burji Mamluks. The Bahris were ethnically Turkic from the southern Russian steppes with a mixture of other races including Kurds and also Mongols. The Burjis were Circassians from the Christian areas of the northern Caucasus. The Mamluks continued the strongly Sunni policy of the Ayyubids with the sultans, governors and amirs founding numerous mosques, madrasas and other religious and charitable institutions in Cairo, Damascus, Aleppo and elsewhere. They saw their role as defenders of Islam against the infidel Mongols, Frankish crusaders and heterodox Muslims in the mountains of western Syria. Egypt and Syria enjoyed considerable prosperity under the Mamluks until the 15th century.
p08m57hhcgp.label: Mamluk dynasty

p08m57hp9sx.label: Urartian
p08m57hp9sx.note: An Iron Age culture of eastern Turkey named after the kingdom of Urartu (c 860-585 BC) centred around Lake Van. At its height, the Urartian kingdom extended north into modern Armenia and southern Georgia; west to the sources of the River Euphrates in Turkey; east to modern Lake Urmia and south to the sources of the River Tigris. Urartu passed into the hands of the Orontid kingdom of Armenia after invasions by Scythians and Medes from the areas of modern Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan and Iran around 612 BC.

p08m57hq7bs.label: Epi-palaeolithic
p08m57hq7bs.note: Term used in Africa, Middle East and parts of Europe for assemblages of the early recent or Holocene period, after the end of the last Ice Age and before the beginning of farming, approximately 12,000-6,000BC.  These assemblages were used by hunter-gatherers and show few changes in content or technology from the preceding Upper Palaeolithic period except in the greater numbers of backed blades, crescents and microliths. This similarity gives rise to the term epi (like)-palaeolithic.  In northern Europe, environmental change was much greater at the end of the Ice Age, human adaptations changed in response and, consequently, the stone artefact assemblages are much different from those of the Upper Palaeolithic and are distinguished as Mesolithic. Despite this distinction the terms Epi-palaeolithic and Mesolithic are occasionally used as if synonymous.
p08m57hq7bs.spatialCoverageDescription: Africa, Middle East and parts of Europe

p08m57hgrmh.note: 1650 BC-1050 BC.  The third major division of the Cypriot Bronze Age is marked by the appearance of new pottery types, such as White Slip, Base Ring and Monochrome in the North West of the island, which gradually replace older fabrics which continue in use from the Middle Bronze Age. Other important fabrics included Bichrome Wheelmade, Red Lustrous Wheelmade and various Plain and Painted Wheelmade wares; the latter are heavily influenced by imports from the Mycenaean world in particular (but also the Levant) which gradually displace the older hand-made wares by the 12th century.  The period is characterised by a thriving copper extraction industry, intense commercial interchange with surrounding regions – with imports visible from all around the Eastern Mediterranean - , and the emergence of more complex forms of social organisation, which can be called towns by LCIIC and LCIIIA. Literacy is attested in the form of documents written in a script called Cypro-Minoan, which has some links with Bronze Age Crete.  The last phase of the LC period, LCIII is a transitional period marked by major changes in the settlement pattern, burial practices, economy and material culture (including pottery types); the development of Proto-White Painted and Proto-Bichrome wares signal the beginning of the Iron Age in ceramic terms. The development of iron-making technology, in which Cypriot metallurgists played a leading role, develops apace at this time.
p08m57hgrmh.label: Late Cypriot

p08m57h35dv.note: 1008-1051 (AH 398-AH 443). Petty Kurdish and Daylami dynasty of the Zagros region when the power of the Buyids (q.v.) began to fade. With the rise of the Seljuqs in Persia the Kakwayhid's lost their independence and were reduced to vasaledge. Muhammad known as Ibn Kakuya, who was the son of Dushmanziyar, was the governor of Isfahan in 1008 (AH 398). He soon expanded his power to Hamadan and Kurdistan and his court circle included the philosopher and physian Ibn Sina (Avicenna) who functioned as his vizier.

p08m57h2wzt.note: Chauhan dynasty (fl. 8th-12th century) was first established at Sambhar, the salt lake area in the Amber (later Jaipur) district, Rajasthan. In the early 11th century Ajayaraja (q.v.) founded the city of Ajayameru (Ajmer), and in the mid twelfth century, his successor Vigraharaja (q.v.) captured Delhi from the Tomaras (q.v.) and annexed territory along the Yamuna River. In 12th century the Chauhans dominated Delhi, Ajmer and Ranthambhor. The last king, Prithviraja III (q.v.), resisted Muslim attack at Tarain in 1191, but was defeated by Muhammad ibn Sam (q.v.) in a second battle at Tarain in 1192.
p08m57h2wzt.label: Chauhan dynasty

p08m57hvzvk.note: 1169-1260 (AH 564-AH 658). Dynasty of Kurdish origin whose most famous ruler was Saladin I, the founder of the Ayyubid dynasty in Damascus. He conquered Fatimid Egypt and replaced Isma'ili Shi'ism with strong orthodox Sunni religious and educational policy. The Ayyubids were continuing the policy of the Zangids in Syria and the earlier Great Seljuqs. After the death of the Ayyubid al-Kamil Nasir al-Din Muhammad in 1238 (AH 635) internal quarrels turned the Ayyubid empire into a confederation of principalities. The Mongol invasion put an end to Ayyubid rule.

p08m57h8x32.label: Pre-Pottery Neolithic B
p08m57h8x32.note: The Pre-Pottery Neolithic B (PPNB) (9,200-8,000 BP) is a division of the Neolithic named by Kathleen Kenyon during her excavations at Jericho.  The PPNB encompasses a major transition in the lifestyles of the inhabitants of the Mediterranean coast of the Middle East. The population increased and significant common traits within what has been termed an ‘Interaction Sphere’  include chipped stone typologies, subsistence based on cultivation and herding, rectangular architecture, the utilisation of burnt lime plaster and ritual practices focussed on skulls, symbolic statuary and baked clay figurines.

p08m57h8c8c.label: North Eastern British Iron Age
p08m57h8c8c.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 60 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Lincolnshire and parts of Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Leicestershire and Rutland, in which similar styled coinages are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include VEP CORF, AVN COST, IISVPRASV, TATISOM and VOLISIOS. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Corieltavi (formerly "Corieltauvi" or "Coritani"), who inhabited a similar area in the early Roman period. Other groups, however, may have existed in this area before AD 43.

p08m57hvrzw.note: 995-1231 (AH 385-AH 628). Khwarazm is the classical Chorasmia, the rich and well irrigated region on the lower Oxus. In later times it was known as the Khanate of Khiva. It may have been an early home of the Iranians. Khwarazm was under Samanid rule until it was added to the Ghaznavid empire under Mahmud in 1017 (AH 408). After the middle of the 11th century Khwarazm was under Seljuq rule. Since the time of Malik Shah the hereditary governors of Khwarazm received the title of Khwarazm Shah. After the conquest of Transoxiana by Genghis Khan in 1220 (AH 617) Khwarazm came first under the rule of Mongols and then Turkish Central Asian steppe peoples.

p08m57h2kf3.note: 861-1003 (AH 247-AH 393). Dynasty in Eastern Persia. Ya'qub and his brother 'Amr derived their name from their founders trade of coppersmith (Saffar). The province of Sistan became the centre of a vast empire which covered almost all of Persia, except for the north-west and the Caspian region. The empire stretched to the frontiers of India. The Saffarids openly proclaimed their contempt for the 'Abbasids and effectively demolished the 'caliphal fiction'.

p08m57hpcqv.label: British Iron Age Kent
p08m57hpcqv.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 150 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to the modern county of Kent and parts of East Sussex and Greater London, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Probable rulers in this area include Dubnovellaunos, Sam, Vosenos, Eppillus, Solidu and Amminius. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain uncertain, although many modern books label them as "Cantii" or "Cantiaci". In fact, this area may well have been fragmented before the Roman period. The term "South Eastern" is used in Hobbs' catalogue of the BM collection (1996) but is often considered confusing.  R Hobbs, British Iron Age Coins in the British Museum, London (BMP) 1996.

p08m57hph3k.label: Punic
p08m57hph3k.note: This term refers to the Punic, western Mediterranean culture contemporary with the Iron Age and Roman Republican period. The culture exhibits elements of Greco-Roman culture but is essentially autonomous. It refers to Carthage and its settlements established in Sardinia, Spain and Western Sicily, and also to those settlements of North Africa around Carthage.  It is related to the Classical World but also to Levantine cultures as its origins are from the Phoenician settlements. This culture may thus be taken back as far as the foundation of Carthage in the 9th century (Roman sources date it to 814 BC) until its destruction by the Romans in 146 BC, but also may extend as far into the Early Modern period when it was refounded by the Romans until it was again destroyed circa AD 698.
p08m57hph3k.spatialCoverageDescription: Carthage and its settlements established in Sardinia, Spain and Western Sicily, and also to those settlements of North Africa around Carthage

p08m57htdjj.spatialCoverageDescription: north-eastern Iraq and Kurdistan; northern Syria

p08m57hjch7.note: The term Arab-Sasanian covers the period circa 651-794 (AH 31-AH 178) and  is used for early Islamic coins with Pahlavi and/or Arabic legends which were struck in the Sasanian fashion with the conventional Sasanian portrait on the obverse and on the reverse with a Zoroastrian fire-altar and two attendants. These coins were issued by the Arabs and Muslim authorities who governed the Sasanian provinces after the overthrow of the Sasanian empire. This coin type persisted in the eastern provinces of the caliphate for almost 200 years.  The Yazdgird Era, commonly abbreviated as YE, is the first era inscribed on Tabaristan coins and on some Arab-Sasanian coins. YE1 (ie. year 1 of the Yazdgird Era) corresponds to AD 632/633, the first regnal year of the last Sasanian ruler Yazdgird III (632/3-651).
p08m57hjch7.label: Arab-Sasanian

p08m57hvfzk.note: 1370-1507  (AH 7721-AH 913). Dynasty named after Timur Lang (Tamerlain) who came from the Barlas clan of Turkicised Mongols. Timur acquired the title guregen/kureken, Mongolian for 'royal son-in-law' because of his marriage to a Chingizid princess. Timur was interested in settled lands of ancient Islamic or Indian culture and eventually built his capital at Samarkand (modern Uzbekistan). His rise to power began in Transoxiana. The later Timurids were mere local rulers in Khurasan and Transoxiana. The Timurid period was one of the most glorious periods in Medieval Islamic art in Transoxiana and Persia.
p08m57hvfzk.label: Timurid dynasty

p08m57hnp58.note: Rajput dynasty of northern India who founded Delhi as their capital in the 10th century. They were conquered by the Chauhan ruler Vigraharaja IV (q.v) c. 1152, but continued to rule Delhi, possibly as Chauhan feudatories until c. 1167.
p08m57hnp58.label: Tomara dynasty

p08m57hxrdm.note: An Iron Age culture of western Turkey named after the kingdom of Lydia (c1300-546 BC). At its greatest extent the kingdom covered all of western Turkey and its capital was the city of Sardis. Coins were invented in Lydia around  660 BC. In 546 BC king Cyrus II captured Sardis and Lydia became part of the Achaemenid empire. The region never regained independence and was subsequently ruled by Alexander the Great and then the Seleucid dynasty.
p08m57hxrdm.label: Lydian

p08m57ht5pw.note: The Aq Qoyunlu '[those with] white sheep' were a nomadic Turkmen confederation centred on Diyar Bakr 1378-1508 (AH 780-908), who established power through marital alliances with the Byzantines in the later 14th century. They submitted to Timur (q.v.) and were rewarded with the grant of Diyar Bakr. Under Uzun Hasan (1457-1478), they extended their rule as far as Khurasan, Iraq and the Persian Gulf, but were overthrown by the Ottomans (q.v.) and Safavids (q.v.).

p08m57h97b5.note: The term ‘Mycenaean' was originally used to describe Greek Bronze Age material of the period 1600BC-1060BC , following the discoveries made at the site of Mycenae by Heinrich Schliemann in the 19th century. Subsequently the term Helladic was introduced for material produced on mainland Greece during the Bronze Age, as a counterpart to Minoan and Cycladic. However, ‘Mycenaean’ continues to be used to describe Late Bronze Age Greek material culture, particularly that relating to the palatial era, when sites such as Mycenae flourished.  The term 'Mycenaean' is used in preference to ‘Late Helladic’. Where a specific 'Late Helladic' sub-division term (such as 'Late Helladic I') can be defined, particularly in the case of pottery, the specific sub-division term should be used instead of 'Mycenaean'.

p08m57h9nf5.note: The term refers to the successor state to the Roman empire in the eastern Mediterranean, from the foundation  of Constantinople by Constantine the Great in AD 330 until its fall to the Ottoman Turks in AD 1453. The Byzantine period is often divided into three phases: the early Byzantine period from the early 4thC to the 7thC (see also the term Late Antique) which saw the losses of the key provinces of Syria and Egypt to the Arabs; the Middle Byzantine period from the 8thC to the early 13thC covering Iconoclasm and ending with the sack of Constantinople by the Fourth Crusade in 1204; the Late Byzantine period from the early 13thC to the mid-15thC, a period of geographical and political decline, but also of a flowering of the arts under the Palaeologan dynasty.  See also the terms Late Roman and Medieval and its Narrow Terms.

p08m57hwkmv.note: ca. 2400/2300 BC-2000/1900 BC.  The first division of the Cypriot Bronze Age, characterised by the use of Red Polished pottery, simple bronze tools and burials in chamber tombs usually placed outside the settlement areas. The beginning of the period overlaps with the Late Chalcolithic in some part of Cyprus, especially the west of the island, and with the Philia culture which has links with contemporary Anatolia (not represented in the BM collection).

p08m57hdw58.label: Western British Iron Age
p08m57hdw58.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 50 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Gloucestershire, Avon and western Oxfordshire, parts and parts of Herefordshire, Worcestershire, Warwickshire, Berkshire, Wiltshire and Somerset. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include BODVOC, CORIO, COMVX, CATTI, ANTED and EISV. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Dobunni who inhabited a similar area in the early Roman period. Other groups, however, may have existed in this area before AD 43.
p08m57hdw58.spatialCoverageDescription: Gloucestershire, Avon and western Oxfordshire, parts and parts of Herefordshire, Worcestershire, Warwickshire, Berkshire, Wiltshire and Somerset

p08m57hsmnr.label: Achaemenid Dynasty
p08m57hsmnr.note: Iranian dynasty owing its origins to Teispes, son of Achaemenes. Originally kings of a territory called Anshan, subject to Median control, Persian independence was attained around 550 BC by Cyrus II (“The Great”). Cyrus conquered Babylon in 539 BC. The empire grew to control a vast territory extending from India to Egypt. The Achaemenids were brought to an end in 331 BC, following the victory of Alexander of Macedon over Darius III’s troops at the Battle of Gaugamela.

p08m57h65g5.label: La Tène
p08m57h65g5.note: Western Europe: 450BC-43AD.  The term La Tène is used to describe the material culture of the latter half of the Iron Age across much of northern and western Europe, from 450BC to the Roman conquest. The name is derived from a site on Lake Neuchâtel, Switzerland, where the first 'La Tène' type objects were excavated in the late 19thC.  In addition to describing a broad chronological timeframe, the term La Tène is also used to refer to certain types of object characteristic of this period, for example a La Tène sword or brooch. La Tène can be subdivided into La Tène I, II and III, or La Tène A, B, C and D. Using these subdivisions well established typologies of La Tène objects have been created. For example, the attachment of the foot to the bow on La Tène brooches follows a pattern which is consistent over time and across much of Europe. For example, the foot of a La Tène I brooch is not attached to the bow. If a brooch of this type is discovered it is an important piece of dating evidence for other types of object.

Further territorial expansion southwards brought the kingdom into conflict with the British. Following the treaty of Sagauli in 1815, a British Resident was installed in Kathmandu. Men from this region are still recruited into the elite Gorkha regiment of the British army.

p08m57hz828.label: Umayyad dynasty
p08m57hz828.note: 661-750 (AH 41-AH132). First Islamic dynasty of caliphs, founded by Muawiya after the murder of  'Ali. The capital of the Umayyads was Damascus and from here the caliphs ruled over vast heterogenious territories. They adopted adminstrative practices of the Greeks and the Persians, the former rulers of the conquered lands. They introduced Sasanian techniques and manners which were strengthened under the 'Abbasids. During the reign of Walid I (705-715/AH 86-AH 96) they expanded militarily. All of North Africa west of Egypt was occupied and Muslim raiders crossed the Straits of Gibraltar into Spain. Beyond the Caucasus contact was made with the Turkish Khazars. In eastern Iran Khwarazm was invaded and Transonania gradually conquered. There was opposition from native Iranian rulers and their Turkish allies. Within the heartlands the caliphs faced constant opposition of Arab tribesman of Iraq. The Umayyads saw themselves not just as successors of the Prophet but as god's own deputies hense their title Khalifat Allah meaning 'god's caliph'. After 746 (AH 128) a revoltutionary movement began in Khurasan under 'Abu Muslim and the anti Umayyad forces gained military victory. This resulted in the succession of the 'Abbasids to the caliphate in 750 (AH 132).
p08m57hz828.spatialCoverageDescription: Damascus, Syria; All of North Africa west of Egypt; Spain

p08m57hwwtz.note: 749-1258 (AH 132-AH 923). Dynasty ruling the Muslim world as caliphs with Iraq at it's centre and Baghdad it's capital. The Abbasids derived from the family of the Prophet Muhammad's uncle al-'Abbas and the Meccan clan of Hashim. The Abbasids were influenced by older Persian traditions of divine rulership. The Abbasid revolution, while in origin an Arab movement, began on Persian soil and took advantage of discontent in the Persian lands. The shifting of the capital from Damascus under the Umayyads to Baghdad in Iraq symbolised a new eastward orientation of the caliphate with increasingly evident Persian material and cultural practives of the next centuries. The Abbasid caliphs adopted honorific titles expressing divine support for their rule. The first three centuries of Abbasid rule saw the full flowering of medieval Islamic civilisation and influences coming in from Persia and the Hellenistic and Byzantine cultures. The Abbasid ruler best known in the West is Harun al-Rashid (786-809 AH 170-193), who is associated with the stories of 1001 Nights.
p08m57hwwtz.label: Abbasid dynasty

p08m57hfw73.note: 1256-1353 (AH 654-AH 754). The Mongol Il-Khanids were rulers of the regions of Persia, Iraq, Transcaucasia and Anatolia. Hulegu (Huluku), son of Toluy, adopted the title of Il-Khan meaning territorial Khan and subordinate to the Great Khan. The capitals of the Il-Khanid's of Persia were Tabriz and Maragha in the north-west, and later at Sultaniyya near Qazwin.

p08m57h586b.note: Central Asian people of Sogdiana or Sogdia, centred on the fertile Zeravsham valley around Samarqand in Uzbekistan. It was a province of the Achaemenids (q.v.), invaded by Alexander the Great (q.v.), and was part of the Bactrian Greek kingdom until the Sogdians appear to have broken away c.200 BC and begun minting their own coins. The region was subsequently invaded by the Indo-Scythian (q.v.) and Yuezhi (q.v.) nomadic tribes in the 2nd century BC, but nevertheless remained a prosperous centre until the Mongol (q.v.) invasions in the early 13th century.  The Sogdians occupied a key position along the ancient Silk Road and, from the early 3rd century BC until the 10th century AD, played a major role in facilitating trade between China and Central Asia. They were the dominant merchants, their language became the lingua franca of the Silk Road, and they played an important role not only in trade but also in the spread of philosophies and religions, such as Manichaeism and Buddhism, to the east.
p08m57h586b.label: Sogdian

p08m57hdng4.note: For the British Isles, the term refers to the period from about AD 400 to about AD 1050. The term 'Celtic' is used to refer generally to Early Medieval objects from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Cornwall, ie. the non-Anglo-Saxon areas.   For Continental Europe, for the western territories of the former Roman Empire (Italy, France, Spain, etc.) the Early Medieval period is generally accepted to begin in around AD 400. For the eastern Roman Empire, the term Byzantine is used.   N.B.   For all European coins, the term 'Medieval' (rather than the Narrow Terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval') is used as a general term for the period c. 400 to c. 1500. Other term can also be entered, such as 'Burgundian'.

p08m57h6mcm.note: 931-c.1090 (AH 319-AH 413). Local dynasty in the remote highland region of Daylam at the south-west corner of the Caspian Sea. The Ziyarids descended from Mardawij ibn Ziyar of the royal clan of Gilan. His power extended as far south as Isfahan and Hamadan but he was murdered in 935 (AH 323) by his own Turkish slave troops. The Ziyarids lost their power but Mardawij's brother, Wushmgir, retained a foot hold in the eastern Caspian provinces by acknowledging as his overlords the Samanids. In the 11th century the Ziyarids has to recognise the overlordship of the Ghnazvids and survived as vassals of the Seljuqs in the highland region.
p08m57h6mcm.label: Ziyarid dynasty

Invasions by Cimmerians, nomads from the Ukraine and Russia, around 700BC culminated in the capture of Gordion in 696 BC, but Phrygian art and culture continued to flourish. Lydians then took over the territory in the 620s BC until the capture of Sardis by king Cyrus II in 546 BC when Lydia became part of the Achaemenid empire.

p08m57hv4pv.note: 977-1186 (AH 366-AH 582). Khurasan, Afghanistan, northern India. Rulers played main part in expansion of Islam into India. With the adoption of Persian administrative and cultural ways the Ghaznavid abandoned their original Turkish steppe background and became largely integrated with the Perso-Islamic tradition. Under Mas'ud I, the son of Mahmud I, the Ghaznavid empire could not be maintained in the west against the Seljuqs, and Khwarazm, Khurasan and northern Persia were lost. The rise of the Ghurids reduced the power of the Ghaznavids and the dynasty was extinguished in 1186 (AH 582).
p08m57hv4pv.label: Ghaznavid dynasty

Sogdiana broke away in turn from Bactria c. 200 BC; the rest of the region was lost to nomadic tribes of the Indo-Scythians and Yuezhi by c. 145 BC.

p08m57hppss.note: The term refers to a specific independent Greek kingdom (c.180 BC-AD 10), ruling in Afghanistan south of the Hindu Kush mountains and north-western Pakistan up to the Indus and Sutlej rivers (i.e. including the Punjab).  The Indo-Greeks lost Afghanistan and most of Pakistan to Indo-Scythians c. 70 BC, but survived in the Punjab until c. AD 10. They are the successors to the Greco-Bactrians, who broke away from the Seleucid empire c. 250 BC to form an independent Greek kingdom in Bactria (Afghanistan north of the Hindu Kush) and Sogdiana (modern Tajikistan), which was lost to nomadic tribes of the Indo-Scythians and Yuezhi by c. 100 BC.
p08m57hppss.label: Indo-Greek

p08m57hgs5w.note: 1040-1194 (AH 431-AH 590). Turkic dynasty ruling in Persia, Iraq and Syria that  reunited central 'Abbasid lands. The Seljuqs had originally their home in the steppes north of the Caspian and Aral Seas. They converted to Islam at the end of the 10th century. Under Toghril I Beg they seized Nishapur, the capital of the Ghaznavids in 1038 (AH 429). He entered Baghdad in 1055 (AH 447) and had his title of sultan confirmed by the caliph. The sultanate of the Great Seljuqs was based on a hierarchically organised state in the Perso-Islamic monarchic system, with the supreme sultan supported by a Perian and Arab beaurocracy and a multi-national army directed by Turkish slave commanders. Under Alp Arslan and his son Malik Shah the Great Seljuq empire reached its zenith and Isfahan was the capital. The Seljuqs founded various orthodox Sunni madrasas or religious colleges in Irag and the Persian lands and encouraged a synthesis of traditional theological and legal studies with the spirit of Sufism.
p08m57hgs5w.label: Seljuq dynasty

p08m57hg45z.label: Southern British Iron Age
p08m57hg45z.note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Hampshire and West Sussex, parts of Kent, East Sussex, Surrey, Berkshire and Wiltshire, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Notable rulers in this area include Commios, Tincomarus, Eppillus, Verica and Epaticcus. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain unclear, but they may have belonged to the Atrebates, Regni (or Regini) or Belgae (all attested districts of the later Roman province).  J Creighton, Coins and Power in Iron Age Britain, Cambridge (CUP) 2000.

Pictorial art on vases develops considerably, while three-dimensional representation, in the form of stone and terracotta statues deposited in large numbers in tombs, reaches impressive levels.

p08m57h7t8h.note: The Kalachuris who ruled from Ratanpur from the early 11th century were distantly related to, and feudatories of, the Tripuri Kalachuris. They gained prominence under Jajalladeva I in the early 12th century. Early historical documents of their rule continue to Pratapamalla (reigned c. 1188-1217) and are then interrupted until the 15th century, by which time the family had split into two branches based at Ratanpur and Raipur. p08m57hkp2w.editorialNote: Spatial coverage inferred from period name.

p08m57h96rf.note: This term refers to the Greek colonies established at Emporion and Rhode in the 6thC BC which flourished until the Roman conquest of Spain in the late 3rdC BC-early 2ndC BC. It also refers to the indigenous cultures of Spain, or Iberians, contemporary to the aformentioned colonies. This includes the coinage minted by those settlements in the vicinity of Emporion and Rhode and also those minted by those colonies themselves.
p08m57h96rf.spatialCoverageDescription: Greek colonies established at Emporion and Rhode
p08m57h96rf.label: Graeco-Iberian

p08m57hbdv4.note: With the collapse of strong control at Babylon around 1600 BC, a dynasty of Kassite kings, whose original homeland may have been in the mountains to the east, was able to claim the throne and eventually united the cities of southern Mesopotamia into a single country, Babylonia. The last Kassite king was defeated by the Elamites of southwest Iran in 1155 BC.
p08m57hbdv4.label: Kassite

p08m57hrsqf.note: The terms refer to a period of the San Agustin cultural tradition of Colombia in the upper Magdalena valley in the Huila department from 1 AD to 900 AD.
p08m57hrsqf.label: San Agustin Regional Classic

p08m57h4jbc.label: Xin dynasty
p08m57h4jbc.editorialNote: Spatial coverage inferred from period name.

p08m57h9qtw.note: 819-1005 (AH 204-AH 395). Dynasty of local land owners in Khurasan and Transoxania who claimed descent from pre-Islamic Sasanian emperors of Iran. New Persian language and literature flourished under Samanid rule. In the middle of the 10th century a series of revolts resulted in decentralisation and enabled the Qarakhanids and Ghaznavids to cease control over Samanid territories in 1005 (AH 395).
p08m57h9qtw.label: Samanid dynasty

p08m57h65c8.note: The Roman Republic is traditionally said to date from the expulsion of the last King of Rome in 510 BC. The end of the Republic can be dated to the battle of Actium in 31 BC or the date when Octavian took the title of Augustus in 27 BC. The former date is generally used for coins. For material issued in areas of Italy outside Roman rule during this period see 'Italic'.
p08m57h65c8.label: Roman Republican
p08m57h65c8.editorialNote: Spatial coverage inferred from period name and temporal extent.

p08m57h5crt.note: A term used for a dynasty of rulers of the city-state of Lagash in southern Mesopotamia who expanded their authority following the collapse of the Akkadian empire around 2190 BC. Lagash was eventually absorbed into the kingdom of the Third Dynasty of Ur after 2100 BC.

p08m57hgwp5.note: 909-1171 (AH 297-AH 555). Rulers of North Africa, then Egypt and southern Syria who claimed title of caliph. They claimed descent from Fatima the daughter of the Prophet Mohammad and wife of the fourth Caliph 'Ali. In 909 (AH 297) the Mahdi was proclaimed caliph in rivalry to the 'Abbasids of Baghdad. From Egypt the Fatimids extended into Palestine and Syria and reached the zenith of their power in the 11th century.
