source.title: Peintures antiques et inédites de vases grecs, tirées de diverses collections, avec des explications

start.label: au temps de la seconde guerre Punique

p044mt9m8zd.label: La troisième époque
p044mt9m8zd.editorialNote:
ISO values for Earliest and Latest Starts and Stops inferred from standard modern chronologies for Second Punic and Social Wars (cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Punic_War#cite_ref-1 and https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_War_(91%E2%80%9388_BC). "La seconde guerre Punique" is inferred from the reference to "cette guerre" at viii n. 9.

Though the source determines the chronological parameters of this period based on political fluctuations that took place primarily if not exclusively in the Italian peninsula and Magna Graecia, his introduction (cf. pp. i-vii) foregrounds his discussion of Greek vase painting as encompassing works made both in Italy and in Greece (see, e.g.,  his discussion of Corinthian pottery on pp. vii and ix). I therefore included Greece in the spatial coverage of this Period.
p044mt9m8zd.note:
La troisième époque commenceroit au temps de cette guerre désastrueuse et se prolongeroit jusqu'à la guerre Sociale qui ruina de fond en comble l'Italie, et y détruisit entièrement la civilisation et toutes les institutions que les Grecs y avoient apportées. [cf. Millingen 1813, viii n. 9]  Ce fut probablement alors que cessa la fabrication des vases peints."

[Millingen 1813, viii n. 9]: "Du temps d'Auguste, toute la Grande-Grèce étoit tombée dans la barbarie, à l'exception de Naples, de Rhegium, et de Tarente, Strabo, lib. VI pag. a53. Edit. 1620"

p044mt9z8hr.label: La première époque
p044mt9z8hr.note:
"On sait l'extrème difficulté qu'il y a de fixer l'époque des monumens anciens avec quelque dégré de précision, soit en les considérant d'après le style de l'Art, soit d'après les principes de la paléographie, lorsqu'ils présentent des caractères. Mais en combinant ce qu'ont rapporté les auteurs anciens avec les monumens de toute espèce, surtout les médailles et les inscriptions, il semble qu'on peut établir trois époques principales." (Millingen 1813, viii)

cf. Millingen 1813, n. 6: "V. Planches XX à XXII, XXXI, XXXII".

p044mt93nd6.label: La seconde époque
p044mt93nd6.editorialNote:
"The Fine Style" alternate label from Birch 1858, 222 (citing Millingen 1813, viii).

Earliest and Latest Stop ISO values inferred from modern chronology of Second Punic War (cf. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Punic_War#cite_ref-1).
p044mt93nd6.note:
"La seconde [époque] commençnt à l'année 450, temps où ont fleuri Polygnote [cf. n. 7] et Phidias, est celle où l'Art a atteint son plus haut dégré de perfection [cf. n. 8] elle finiroit quant à l'Italie et à la Sicile, vers la seconde guerre Punique."

[Millingen 1813, viii n. 7]: "'Polygnote, qui florissoit dans la LXXXIIIème Olympiade (444. ans avant notre ére) fut le premier qui peignit des femmes avec des vêtemens transparens, des coëffures de différentes couleurs et qui contribua le premier à la perfection de l'Art, car il établit l'usage d'ouvrir la bouche aux figures, de faire voir les dents, de changer l'ancienne roideur des attitudes, Plin. Hist. Nat. lib. XXXV. cap. 9.'"

[Millingen 1813, viii, n. 8]: "L'Art paroit n'être parvenu à sa perfection que du temps de Polygnote et de Phidias. Il est probable que sa marche n'à pas été tout à fait graduelle, mais qu'il prit un essor sous ces grands artistes, comme celui que Raphaël fit prendre à l'art moderne."

partOf.title: Sasanian Iran, 224- 651 CE : portrait of a late antique empire
The energy expansions of evolution

p0323gx.editorialNote: Judson, O. P. The energy expansions of evolution. Nat. Ecol. Evol. 1, 0138 (2017).

p0323gxds6f.label: Energy epoch five: fire
p0323gxds6f.editorialNote: The current epoch has no real end date, since this source of energy has not yet been superceded by another.
p0323gxds6f.note: Source identifies two phases, the earliest of which begins with "the evolution of a fire creature... [that] began to control the use of fire, deliberately setting fires alight and using fire for cooking," and the later of which might be given a beginning at a number of key points ("the burning of fossil fuels such as coal to generate heat and light", "the invention of the internal combustion engine", or "the discovery of the Haber-Bosch process for fixing nitrogen").

start.label: Between 2.45 and 2.32 Ga (The Great Oxidation Event)

p0323gxrm53.label: Energy epoch three: oxygen
p0323gxrm53.editorialNote: The source notes that these epochs are agglomerative: that is, the geochemical epoch does not stop when the sunlight epoch begins, but continues to the present. For the sake of clarity, however, I have marked an end where a given form of energy generation ceases to be the predominant one.

p0323gxv8wc.label: Energy epoch four: flesh
p0323gxv8wc.editorialNote: The source notes that these epochs are agglomerative: that is, the geochemical epoch does not stop when the sunlight epoch begins, but continues to the present. For the sake of clarity, however, I have marked an end where a given form of energy generation ceases to be the predominant one. The end of this epoch is given as the range of estimates for the human use of fire for cooking.

p0323gxcztt.label: Energy epoch two: sunlight
p0323gxcztt.editorialNote: The source notes that these epochs are agglomerative: that is, the geochemical epoch does not stop when the sunlight epoch begins, but continues to the present. For the sake of clarity, however, I have marked an end where a given form of energy generation ceases to be the predominant one. The end of this epoch is given as the range of the Great Oxidation Event.
p0323gxcztt.note: "For [the start of this epoch] I have taken the earliest date for which there is evidence consistent with photosynthesis", citing Rosing, M. 13C-depleted carbon microparticles in >3700-Ma sea-floor sedimentary rocks from west Greenland. Science 283, 674–676 (1999); Pecoits, E. et al. Atmospheric hydrogen peroxide and Eoarchean iron formations. Geobiology 13, 1–14 (2015); Nutman, A. P., Bennett, V. C., Friend, C. R. L., Van Kranendonk, M. J. & Chivas, A. R. Rapid emergence of life shown by discovery of 3,700-million-year-old microbial structures. Nature 537, 535–538 (2016).

p0323gx5nk4.label: Energy epoch one: geochemical energy
p0323gx5nk4.editorialNote: The source notes that these epochs are agglomerative: that is, the geochemical epoch does not stop when the sunlight epoch begins, but continues to the present. For the sake of clarity, however, I have marked an end where a given form of energy generation ceases to be the predominant one.
p0323gx5nk4.note: "For [the start of this epoch] I have taken the earliest date for which there is evidence consistent with life", citing Bell, E. A., Boehnke, P., Harrison, T. M. & Mao, W. L. Potentially biogenic carbon preserved in a 4.1 billion-year-old zircon. Proc. Natl Acad. Sci. USA 112, 14518–14521 (2015).

partOf.title: The Greek Neolithic: A New Review
partOf.abstract: The Greek Neolithic, here divided into five phases, is the oldest in Europe. Geographically, it is the closest to the Near East and has thus long been seen as an impoverished derivative of the latter. However, recent research has tended to emphasize the autochthonous nature of Neolithic development in Europe, including Greece. The Greek Neolithic economy, which was based almost entirely on domesticates, and its densely packed, long-lived villages strongly recall the Near East, as do also the early emphasis on fine, decorated, nonculinary pottery and the wealth of figurines. On the other hand, the evolution of stylistic patterns is specifically Greek, although generally related to trends in the Balkans. Originality in the development of the Greek Neolithic is also seen in its latest phase, with apparent decreases, rather than increases, in site density, social differentiation, and, to some extent, long-distance trade. At the same time, however, the dichotomy became much sharper between the rich agricultural plains of northern Greece and the more pastoral(?) regions of the Peloponnese and Cycladic Islands; this presages similar contrasts during the Bronze Age.

partOf.title: Iron Age society and chronology in South-east Kazakhstan

p044n25.editorialNote:
There were some problems with the citation parser during the import of the source. The journal name (Antiquity) is not included. Furthermore, the DOI parser lists the authors in a different order than they appeared in the original article: Chang, Benecke, Grigoriev, Rosen and Tourtellotte. The formatted citation is as follows:

Chang, Claudia, Norbert Benecke, Fedor P. Grigoriev, Arlene M. Rosen, and Perry A. Tourtellotte. 2003. “Iron Age society and chronology in South-east Kazakhstan.” Antiquity 77, 296: 298–312.

p044n259mnf.label: Wusun
p044n259mnf.editorialNote: In A. Rosen, C. Chang, and F. Grigoriev, 2000, "Palaeoenvironments and economy of Iron Age Saka-Wusun agro-pastoralists in southeastern Kazakhstan", Antiquity 74:611-623, the Wusun period in this region is defined as "c. 300 BC-AD 200" and the Saka period as "c. 750-300 BC" (p. 611).
